items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible through much of today, Sunday 28th November. Water levels are likely to remain higher than usual for the next 24 hours. This is due to weather conditions associated with Storm Arwen. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Monday 29th November.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: This flood alert has been removed as coastal conditions have eased and have fallen below a level of concern. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
"River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/11/21, or as the situation changes."

items.description: River Seven catchment
items.message: River levels on the River Seven catchment have fallen below the levels of concern. We continue to monitor the situation. Please check the GOV.UK website for up to date information for the next 5 days.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force. River levels are starting to fall. Flooding of roads and farmland remains possible today Monday 29th November 2021. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

The risk of flooding from Storm Arwen has now reduced.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible through much of today, Sunday 28th November. Water levels are likely to remain higher than usual for the next 24 hours. This is due to weather conditions associated with Storm Arwen. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Monday 29th November.
